awd_titl_txt: Improving Research and Education of Big Data and Cloud Computing at Winston-Salem State University
awd_abstract_narration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities - Undergraduate Program provides support for projects that offer solutions to the severe underrepresentation of African American students in computer science at the undergraduate level. The project at Winston Salem State University will build research capacity among faculty and students in the Department of Computer Science by examining resource management of big data applications on cloud infrastructure. This work will be done in collaboration with Duke University. Undergraduate computer science majors will gain research experiences that may further their interest in pursuing a degree in the discipline, thereby contributing to broadening the participation of underrepresented groups in the discipline.

The project goals are: to build the big data and cloud computing research capacity at Winston-Salem state university; to involve undergraduate students in cutting-edge scientific research; and to enhance educational experiences for computer science majors. The project is exploring research centered around the estimation of a globally efficient and cost effective resource allocation for concurrent MapReduce workloads in a cloud infrastructure so that the configuration ensures meeting service level objectives (SLOs) of various workloads and at the same time minimizing the resources required to achieve this goal. The specific research aims are: to leverage a profile and prediction subsystem in order to characterize and model the performance of a MapReduce workload and identify them accordingly as small jobs, periodic jobs, and delayed jobs; to investigate the parameters to be included in the utility function that best can capture the priority, deadline, performance characterization and heterogeneity of MapReduce workloads and the heterogeneity and dynamics of underlying cloud infrastructure; to design and develop algorithms and heuristics for utility-based resource management that take advantage of the workload-specific characteristics and deploy them with the goal of meeting SLOs and maximizing cloud utilization; and to evaluate the proposed approach with real-life big data workloads and study their performances, cloud rental costs, and the overall utilization of the cloud resources.

por.por_cntn:
This funded project aimed to build and enhance the big data and cloud computing research and education capacity at Winston-Salem state university (WSSU). Big data and cloud computing collectively offer a paradigm shift in how businesses acquire, use, and manage information technology. This creates the need for the 21st-century workforce to be equipped with foundational knowledge and hands-on experiences in this collective paradigm. 

In order to expose Computer Science (CS) students to a substantial coverage of big data and cloud computing concepts and skills, we argued that the relevant topics need to be integrated into multiple core courses across the CS curriculum rather than creating additional courses and performing a major overhaul of the curriculum. This curriculum across integration is more important for smaller schools that may not have enough resources, flexibility, and expertise to offer and teach standalone courses on these cutting-edge topics. Our approach to including these topics is to develop autonomous competency-based learning modules for specific core courses in which their coverage might find an appropriate context. During 2017-2019, five such modules were developed and deployed across the CS/IT curriculum at WSSU, and 78 CS/IT majors at WSSU were intervened through this effort. The student performance data and survey results showed promising success in attaining student learning outcomes, enhanced engagement, and interests. Additionally, we also noticed an increased student enrollment in the non-required, senior-level, specialized CS courses such as "Big Data and Cloud Computing" (newly developed as part of this project), and "Parallel and Distributed Computing" (existing course). It was evident that the stronger CS students who are likely to pursue graduate studies and research in the future sincerely pursued these advanced courses once they were exposed to the topics through the modular interventions in the lower-level required courses.

In order to reach out to non-CS students and make them aware of the importance of data-based knowledge extraction, this project developed a "Faculty Adopter Award" program where the PI collaborated with faculties from non-CS departments at WSSU and supported and assisted them in developing and deploying data analytics course modules. Four such modules are developed and deployed in courses offered at departments such as Geography, Business Administration, Marketing, and Physical Therapy. The student performance and survey results show that while students overwhelmingly found data science exciting and could see the value of it for societal good, they remain primarily neutral about their desire to explore more of it in their future courses.

Based on this momentum and student interest, in 2019, WSSU started the "Graduate Certificate in Data Analytics" program. The PI was a vital part of that initiative and used her knowledge, experience, and collaboration in developing two out of four courses that are part of this online certificate program. The developed courses are "Big Data Analytics" and "Data Visualization". 

The PI, her collaborators, and student research assistants published and presented the details of the abovementioned pedagogy and interventions in prominent journals and conferences such as JPDC 2021, CCSC 2021, SIGCSE 2017-2020, ItiCSE 2019, SC 2018, IPDPS 2018, NSF PI conference etc. In addition, all developed course modules and resources are publicly available on the project website (http://ibigcloud.altl.org/index.html) and a GitHub repository (https://github.com/CADS-WSSU) for broader adoption.

As part of the project's research component, the PI investigated the proposed utility-based cloud provisioning for Spark Clusters. The PI and the student researchers investigated the characteristic of spark application performance by running them with various configuration settings to gain deep insight into resource provisioning, workload management, etc. The research team implemented a Spark on YARN cluster on the Chameleon Cloud, a large-scale and open cloud research platform funded by the NSF that allows for greater computational power that the PI lack having in-house, and run experiments there with appropriate CPU and I/O bound benchmark applications. The experimental results show that the CPU and I/O bound spark applications exhibit different resource consumptions, and their execution times are significantly impacted by the settings of the configuration parameters, such as the size of the RDD cache, the number of concurrent tasks in each executor, executor configuration (core and memory per executor) etc. Several undergraduate research assistants presented the research findings at 2017-2020 NSF/ERN, 2017 NC-LSAMP, and WSSU Scholarship Day conferences.

Additionally, the PI utilized the experiences and exposures that she received through this NSF award in securing multiple awards from NSF and other federal and state agencies that resulted in receiving ~$2M funding, including a 1.5M funding from UNC ROI to initiate a Center of Applied Data Science (CADS) at WSSU. Two URM graduate students completed their M.Sc dissertations under this project, and 9 URM UG students were exposed to research and professional development opportunities through this project. The PI directly collaborated with 6 WSSU faculties and exposed 27 others to data science by conducting an intensive faculty workshop in 2018.
